title: Huneke's Proof of the Friendship Theorem
content: In this section, the friendship theorem ~ friendship is proven by formalizing Huneke's proof, see [Huneke] pp. 1-2. The three claims (see ~ frgrncvvdeq , ~ frgrregorufr and ~ frrusgrord0 ) and additional statements (numbered in the order of their occurence in the paper) in Huneke's proof are cited in the corresponding theorems.

blocks.name: frgrncvvdeqlem1
blocks.content: Lemma 1 for ~ frgrncvvdeq . (Contributed by Alexander van der Vekens, 23-Dec-2017.) (Revised by AV, 8-May-2021.) (Proof shortened by AV, 12-Feb-2022.)
blocks.origin:
thm frgrncvvdeqlem1(setvar s0, setvar s1, class c0, class c1, class c2, class c3, class c4, class c5, class c6, class c7, wff w0) {
  |- wi(w0, wnel(c0, c1))
  -| wceq(c2, cfv(cvtx, c3))
  -| wceq(c4, cfv(cedg, c3))
  -| wceq(c5, co(c3, cnbgr, c0))
  -| wceq(c1, co(c3, cnbgr, c6))
  -| wi(w0, wcel(c0, c2))
  -| wi(w0, wcel(c6, c2))
  -| wi(w0, wne(c0, c6))
  -| wi(w0, wnel(c6, c5))
  -| wi(w0, wcel(c3, cfrgr))
  -| wceq(c7, cmpt(s0, c5, crio(s1, c1, wcel(cpr(cv(s0), cv(s1)), c4))))
} = {
  a1ii(wi(w0, wnel(c0, c1)), wceq(c2, cfv(cvtx, c3)))
  a1ii(wi(w0, wnel(c0, c1)), wceq(c4, cfv(cedg, c3)))
  a1ii(wi(w0, wnel(c0, c1)), wi(w0, wcel(c0, c2)))
  a1ii(wi(w0, wnel(c0, c1)), wi(w0, wcel(c6, c2)))
  a1ii(wi(w0, wnel(c0, c1)), wi(w0, wne(c0, c6)))
  a1ii(wi(w0, wnel(c0, c1)), wi(w0, wcel(c3, cfrgr)))
  a1ii(wi(w0, wnel(c0, c1)), wceq(c7, cmpt(s0, c5, crio(s1, c1, wcel(cpr(cv(s0), cv(s1)), c4)))))
  sylibr(w0, wnel(c0, c1), wn(wcel(c0, co(c3, cnbgr, c6))))
  sylnibr(w0, wcel(c0, co(c3, cnbgr, c6)), wcel(c6, co(c3, cnbgr, c0)))
  sylib(w0, wn(wcel(c6, co(c3, cnbgr, c0))), wnel(c6, c5))
  xchbinx(wnel(c6, c5), wcel(c6, co(c3, cnbgr, c0)), wcel(c6, c5))
  df-nel(c6, c5)
  eleq2i(c6, c5, co(c3, cnbgr, c0))
  nbgrsym(c0, c3, c6)
  bitri(wnel(c0, c1), wn(wcel(c0, co(c3, cnbgr, c6))), wnel(c0, co(c3, cnbgr, c6)))
  ax-mp(wb(wnel(c0, c1), wnel(c0, co(c3, cnbgr, c6))), wceq(c1, co(c3, cnbgr, c6)))
  neleq2(c1, co(c3, cnbgr, c6), c0)
  df-nel(c0, co(c3, cnbgr, c6))
}
blocks.pretty:
thm frgrncvvdeqlem1(setvar s0, setvar s1, class c0, class c1, class c2, class c3, class c4, class c5, class c6, class c7, wff w0) {
  ‚ä¢ (w0 ‚Üí c0 ‚àâ c1)
  ‚ä£ c2 =(Vtx ` c3)
  ‚ä£ c4 =(Edg ` c3)
  ‚ä£ c5 =(c3[NeighbVtx]c0)
  ‚ä£ c1 =(c3[NeighbVtx]c6)
  ‚ä£ (w0 ‚Üí c0 ‚àà c2)
  ‚ä£ (w0 ‚Üí c6 ‚àà c2)
  ‚ä£ (w0 ‚Üí c0 ‚â† c6)
  ‚ä£ (w0 ‚Üí c6 ‚àâ c5)
  ‚ä£ (w0 ‚Üí c3 ‚àà FriendGraph)
  ‚ä£ c7 =(s0 ‚àà c5 ‚Ü¶ iota(s1 ‚àà c1, { s0, s1 } ‚àà c4))
} = {
  a1ii((w0 ‚Üí c0 ‚àâ c1), c2 =(Vtx ` c3))
  a1ii((w0 ‚Üí c0 ‚àâ c1), c4 =(Edg ` c3))
  a1ii((w0 ‚Üí c0 ‚àâ c1), (w0 ‚Üí c0 ‚àà c2))
  a1ii((w0 ‚Üí c0 ‚àâ c1), (w0 ‚Üí c6 ‚àà c2))
  a1ii((w0 ‚Üí c0 ‚àâ c1), (w0 ‚Üí c0 ‚â† c6))
  a1ii((w0 ‚Üí c0 ‚àâ c1), (w0 ‚Üí c3 ‚àà FriendGraph))
  a1ii((w0 ‚Üí c0 ‚àâ c1), c7 =(s0 ‚àà c5 ‚Ü¶ iota(s1 ‚àà c1, { s0, s1 } ‚àà c4)))
  sylibr(w0, c0 ‚àâ c1, ¬¨ c0 ‚àà(c3[NeighbVtx]c6))
  sylnibr(w0, c0 ‚àà(c3[NeighbVtx]c6), c6 ‚àà(c3[NeighbVtx]c0))
  sylib(w0, ¬¨ c6 ‚àà(c3[NeighbVtx]c0), c6 ‚àâ c5)
  xchbinx(c6 ‚àâ c5, c6 ‚àà(c3[NeighbVtx]c0), c6 ‚àà c5)
  df-nel(c6, c5)
  eleq2i(c6, c5, (c3[NeighbVtx]c0))
  nbgrsym(c0, c3, c6)
  bitri(c0 ‚àâ c1, ¬¨ c0 ‚àà(c3[NeighbVtx]c6), c0 ‚àâ(c3[NeighbVtx]c6))
  ax-mp((c0 ‚àâ c1 ‚Üî c0 ‚àâ(c3[NeighbVtx]c6)), c1 =(c3[NeighbVtx]c6))
  neleq2(c1, (c3[NeighbVtx]c6), c0)
  df-nel(c0, (c3[NeighbVtx]c6))
}

blocks.name: frgrncvvdeqlem2
blocks.content: Lemma 2 for ~ frgrncvvdeq . In a friendship graph, for each neighbor of a vertex there is exactly one neighbor of another vertex so that there is an edge between these two neighbors. (Contributed by Alexander van der Vekens, 22-Dec-2017.) (Revised by AV, 10-May-2021.) (Proof shortened by AV, 12-Feb-2022.)
blocks.origin:
thm frgrncvvdeqlem2(setvar s0, setvar s1, class c0, class c1, class c2, class c3, class c4, class c5, class c6, class c7, wff w0) {
  |- wi(wa(w0, wcel(cv(s0), c0)), wreu(s1, c1, wcel(cpr(cv(s0), cv(s1)), c2)))
  -| wceq(c3, cfv(cvtx, c4))
  -| wceq(c2, cfv(cedg, c4))
  -| wceq(c0, co(c4, cnbgr, c5))
  -| wceq(c1, co(c4, cnbgr, c6))
  -| wi(w0, wcel(c5, c3))
  -| wi(w0, wcel(c6, c3))
  -| wi(w0, wne(c5, c6))
  -| wi(w0, wnel(c6, c0))
  -| wi(w0, wcel(c4, cfrgr))
  -| wceq(c7, cmpt(s0, c0, crio(s1, c1, wcel(cpr(cv(s0), cv(s1)), c2))))
  -| diffss(s0, s1)
  -| diffsc(s1, c3)
  -| diffsc(s1, c4)
  -| diffsc(s1, c6)
} = {
  a1ii(wi(wa(w0, wcel(cv(s0), c0)), wreu(s1, c1, wcel(cpr(cv(s0), cv(s1)), c2))), wi(w0, wcel(c5, c3)))
  a1ii(wi(wa(w0, wcel(cv(s0), c0)), wreu(s1, c1, wcel(cpr(cv(s0), cv(s1)), c2))), wi(w0, wne(c5, c6)))
  a1ii(wi(wa(w0, wcel(cv(s0), c0)), wreu(s1, c1, wcel(cpr(cv(s0), cv(s1)), c2))), wceq(c7, cmpt(s0, c0, crio(s1, c1, wcel(cpr(cv(s0), cv(s1)), c2)))))
  mpd(wa(w0, wcel(cv(s0), c0)), wreu(s1, c1, wcel(cpr(cv(s0), cv(s1)), c2)), wreu(s1, c3, wss(cpr(cpr(cv(s0), cv(s1)), cpr(cv(s1), c6)), c2)))
  sylc(wa(w0, wcel(cv(s0), c0)), wreu(s1, c3, wss(cpr(cpr(cv(s0), cv(s1)), cpr(cv(s1), c6)), c2)), wcel(c4, cfrgr), w3a(wcel(cv(s0), c3), wcel(c6, c3), wne(cv(s0), c6)))
  adantr(w0, wcel(cv(s0), c0), wcel(c4, cfrgr))
  3jca(wa(w0, wcel(cv(s0), c0)), wcel(cv(s0), c3), wcel(c6, c3), wne(cv(s0), c6))
  imp(w0, wcel(cv(s0), c0), wcel(cv(s0), c3))
  syl5bi(w0, wcel(cv(s0), c0), wcel(cv(s0), c3), wcel(cv(s0), co(c4, cnbgr, c5)))
  eleq2i(cv(s0), c0, co(c4, cnbgr, c5))
  a1i(w0, wi(wcel(cv(s0), co(c4, cnbgr, c5)), wcel(cv(s0), c3)))
  nbgrisvtx(cv(s0), c4, c5, c3)
  adantr(w0, wcel(cv(s0), c0), wcel(c6, c3))
  imp(w0, wcel(cv(s0), c0), wne(cv(s0), c6))
  syl(w0, wi(wcel(cv(s0), c0), wne(cv(s0), c6)), wnel(c6, c0))
  expcom(wnel(c6, c0), wcel(cv(s0), c0), wne(cv(s0), c6))
  elnelne2(cv(s0), c0, c6)
  frcond1(s1, c4, cv(s0), c3, c6, c2)
  adantr(w0, wcel(cv(s0), c0), wi(wreu(s1, c3, wss(cpr(cpr(cv(s0), cv(s1)), cpr(cv(s1), c6)), c2)), wreu(s1, c1, wcel(cpr(cv(s0), cv(s1)), c2))))
  3syl(w0, wi(wreu(s1, c3, wss(cpr(cpr(cv(s0), cv(s1)), cpr(cv(s1), c6)), c2)), wreu(s1, c1, wcel(cpr(cv(s0), cv(s1)), c2))), wcel(c4, cfrgr), wcel(c4, cusgr))
  frgrusgr(c4)
  3imtr4g(wcel(c4, cusgr), wreu(s1, c3, wss(cpr(cpr(cv(s0), cv(s1)), cpr(cv(s1), c6)), c2)), wreu(s1, c1, wcel(cpr(cv(s0), cv(s1)), c2)), weu(s1, wa(wcel(cv(s1), c3), wss(cpr(cpr(cv(s0), cv(s1)), cpr(cv(s1), c6)), c2))), weu(s1, wa(wcel(cv(s1), c1), wcel(cpr(cv(s0), cv(s1)), c2))))
  biimpd(wcel(c4, cusgr), weu(s1, wa(wcel(cv(s1), c3), wss(cpr(cpr(cv(s0), cv(s1)), cpr(cv(s1), c6)), c2))), weu(s1, wa(wcel(cv(s1), c1), wcel(cpr(cv(s0), cv(s1)), c2))))
  eubidv(s1, wcel(c4, cusgr), wa(wcel(cv(s1), c3), wss(cpr(cpr(cv(s0), cv(s1)), cpr(cv(s1), c6)), c2)), wa(wcel(cv(s1), c1), wcel(cpr(cv(s0), cv(s1)), c2)))
  bitrd(wcel(c4, cusgr), wa(wcel(cv(s1), c3), wss(cpr(cpr(cv(s0), cv(s1)), cpr(cv(s1), c6)), c2)), wa(wcel(cv(s1), c1), wcel(cpr(cv(s0), cv(s1)), c2)), wa(wcel(cpr(cv(s1), c6), c2), wcel(cpr(cv(s0), cv(s1)), c2)))
  syl6rbbr(wcel(c4, cusgr), wa(wcel(cv(s1), c3), wss(cpr(cpr(cv(s0), cv(s1)), cpr(cv(s1), c6)), c2)), wa(wcel(cpr(cv(s1), c6), c2), wcel(cpr(cv(s0), cv(s1)), c2)), wa(wcel(cv(s1), c3), wa(wcel(cpr(cv(s1), c6), c2), wcel(cpr(cv(s0), cv(s1)), c2))))
  pm4.71rd(wcel(c4, cusgr), wa(wcel(cpr(cv(s1), c6), c2), wcel(cpr(cv(s0), cv(s1)), c2)), wcel(cv(s1), c3))
  adantld(wcel(c4, cusgr), wcel(cpr(cv(s1), c6), c2), wcel(cpr(cv(s0), cv(s1)), c2), wcel(cv(s1), c3))
  syl(wcel(c4, cusgr), wi(wcel(cpr(cv(s0), cv(s1)), c2), wcel(cv(s1), c3)), wcel(c4, cumgr))
  usgrumgr(c4)
  ex(wcel(c4, cumgr), wcel(cpr(cv(s0), cv(s1)), c2), wcel(cv(s1), c3))
  simprd(wa(wcel(c4, cumgr), wcel(cpr(cv(s0), cv(s1)), c2)), wcel(cv(s1), c3), wcel(cv(s0), c3))
  umgrpredgv(c4, cv(s0), cv(s1), c2, c3)
  anbi2i(wcel(cv(s1), c3), wss(cpr(cpr(cv(s0), cv(s1)), cpr(cv(s1), c6)), c2), wa(wcel(cpr(cv(s1), c6), c2), wcel(cpr(cv(s0), cv(s1)), c2)))
  bitr3i(wss(cpr(cpr(cv(s0), cv(s1)), cpr(cv(s1), c6)), c2), wa(wcel(cpr(cv(s1), c6), c2), wcel(cpr(cv(s0), cv(s1)), c2)), wa(wcel(cpr(cv(s0), cv(s1)), c2), wcel(cpr(cv(s1), c6), c2)))
  prss(cpr(cv(s0), cv(s1)), c2, cpr(cv(s1), c6))
  prex(cv(s0), cv(s1))
  prex(cv(s1), c6)
  ancom(wcel(cpr(cv(s0), cv(s1)), c2), wcel(cpr(cv(s1), c6), c2))
  anbi1d(wcel(c4, cusgr), wcel(cpr(cv(s1), c6), c2), wcel(cpr(cv(s0), cv(s1)), c2), wcel(cv(s1), c1))
  syl5rbb(wcel(c4, cusgr), wcel(cpr(cv(s1), c6), c2), wcel(cv(s1), c1), wcel(cv(s1), co(c4, cnbgr, c6)))
  eleq2i(cv(s1), c1, co(c4, cnbgr, c6))
  nbusgreledg(c4, cv(s1), c6, c2)
  df-reu(s1, c3, wss(cpr(cpr(cv(s0), cv(s1)), cpr(cv(s1), c6)), c2))
  df-reu(s1, c1, wcel(cpr(cv(s0), cv(s1)), c2))
  diff.cv.s(s1, s0)
  diffss.ex(s1, s0)
  diff.wcel.s(s1, c4, cusgr)
  diff.cusgr.s(s1)
}

thm frgrncvvdeqlem2(setvar s0, setvar s1, class c0, class c1, class c2, class c3, class c4, class c5, class c6, class c7, wff w0) {
  ‚ä¢ ((w0 ‚àß s0 ‚àà c0)‚Üí ‚àÉ!(s1 ‚àà c1, { s0, s1 } ‚àà c2))
  ‚ä£ c3 =(Vtx ` c4)
  ‚ä£ c2 =(Edg ` c4)
  ‚ä£ c0 =(c4[NeighbVtx]c5)
  ‚ä£ c1 =(c4[NeighbVtx]c6)
  ‚ä£ (w0 ‚Üí c5 ‚àà c3)
  ‚ä£ (w0 ‚Üí c6 ‚àà c3)
  ‚ä£ (w0 ‚Üí c5 ‚â† c6)
  ‚ä£ (w0 ‚Üí c6 ‚àâ c0)
  ‚ä£ (w0 ‚Üí c4 ‚àà FriendGraph)
  ‚ä£ c7 =(s0 ‚àà c0 ‚Ü¶ iota(s1 ‚àà c1, { s0, s1 } ‚àà c2))
  ‚ä£ d(s0, s1)
  ‚ä£ d(s1, c3)
  ‚ä£ d(s1, c4)
  ‚ä£ d(s1, c6)
} = {
  a1ii(((w0 ‚àß s0 ‚àà c0)‚Üí ‚àÉ!(s1 ‚àà c1, { s0, s1 } ‚àà c2)), (w0 ‚Üí c5 ‚àà c3))
  a1ii(((w0 ‚àß s0 ‚àà c0)‚Üí ‚àÉ!(s1 ‚àà c1, { s0, s1 } ‚àà c2)), (w0 ‚Üí c5 ‚â† c6))
  a1ii(((w0 ‚àß s0 ‚àà c0)‚Üí ‚àÉ!(s1 ‚àà c1, { s0, s1 } ‚àà c2)), c7 =(s0 ‚àà c0 ‚Ü¶ iota(s1 ‚àà c1, { s0, s1 } ‚àà c2)))
  mpd((w0 ‚àß s0 ‚àà c0), ‚àÉ!(s1 ‚àà c1, { s0, s1 } ‚àà c2), ‚àÉ!(s1 ‚àà c3, { { s0, s1 }, { s1, c6 } } ‚äÜ c2))
  sylc((w0 ‚àß s0 ‚àà c0), ‚àÉ!(s1 ‚àà c3, { { s0, s1 }, { s1, c6 } } ‚äÜ c2), c4 ‚àà FriendGraph, (s0 ‚àà c3 ‚àß c6 ‚àà c3 ‚àß s0 ‚â† c6))
  adantr(w0, s0 ‚àà c0, c4 ‚àà FriendGraph)
  3jca((w0 ‚àß s0 ‚àà c0), s0 ‚àà c3, c6 ‚àà c3, s0 ‚â† c6)
  imp(w0, s0 ‚àà c0, s0 ‚àà c3)
  syl5bi(w0, s0 ‚àà c0, s0 ‚àà c3, s0 ‚àà(c4[NeighbVtx]c5))
  eleq2i(s0, c0, (c4[NeighbVtx]c5))
  a1i(w0, (s0 ‚àà(c4[NeighbVtx]c5)‚Üí s0 ‚àà c3))
  nbgrisvtx(s0, c4, c5, c3)
  adantr(w0, s0 ‚àà c0, c6 ‚àà c3)
  imp(w0, s0 ‚àà c0, s0 ‚â† c6)
  syl(w0, (s0 ‚àà c0 ‚Üí s0 ‚â† c6), c6 ‚àâ c0)
  expcom(c6 ‚àâ c0, s0 ‚àà c0, s0 ‚â† c6)
  elnelne2(s0, c0, c6)
  frcond1(s1, c4, s0, c3, c6, c2)
  adantr(w0, s0 ‚àà c0, (‚àÉ!(s1 ‚àà c3, { { s0, s1 }, { s1, c6 } } ‚äÜ c2)‚Üí ‚àÉ!(s1 ‚àà c1, { s0, s1 } ‚àà c2)))
  3syl(w0, (‚àÉ!(s1 ‚àà c3, { { s0, s1 }, { s1, c6 } } ‚äÜ c2)‚Üí ‚àÉ!(s1 ‚àà c1, { s0, s1 } ‚àà c2)), c4 ‚àà FriendGraph, c4 ‚àà USGraph)
  frgrusgr(c4)
  3imtr4g(c4 ‚àà USGraph, ‚àÉ!(s1 ‚àà c3, { { s0, s1 }, { s1, c6 } } ‚äÜ c2), ‚àÉ!(s1 ‚àà c1, { s0, s1 } ‚àà c2), ‚àÉ!(s1,(s1 ‚àà c3 ‚àß { { s0, s1 }, { s1, c6 } } ‚äÜ c2)), ‚àÉ!(s1,(s1 ‚àà c1 ‚àß { s0, s1 } ‚àà c2)))
  biimpd(c4 ‚àà USGraph, ‚àÉ!(s1,(s1 ‚àà c3 ‚àß { { s0, s1 }, { s1, c6 } } ‚äÜ c2)), ‚àÉ!(s1,(s1 ‚àà c1 ‚àß { s0, s1 } ‚àà c2)))
  eubidv(s1, c4 ‚àà USGraph, (s1 ‚àà c3 ‚àß { { s0, s1 }, { s1, c6 } } ‚äÜ c2), (s1 ‚àà c1 ‚àß { s0, s1 } ‚àà c2))
  bitrd(c4 ‚àà USGraph, (s1 ‚àà c3 ‚àß { { s0, s1 }, { s1, c6 } } ‚äÜ c2), (s1 ‚àà c1 ‚àß { s0, s1 } ‚àà c2), ({ s1, c6 } ‚àà c2 ‚àß { s0, s1 } ‚àà c2))
  syl6rbbr(c4 ‚àà USGraph, (s1 ‚àà c3 ‚àß { { s0, s1 }, { s1, c6 } } ‚äÜ c2), ({ s1, c6 } ‚àà c2 ‚àß { s0, s1 } ‚àà c2), (s1 ‚àà c3 ‚àß({ s1, c6 } ‚àà c2 ‚àß { s0, s1 } ‚àà c2)))
  pm4.71rd(c4 ‚àà USGraph, ({ s1, c6 } ‚àà c2 ‚àß { s0, s1 } ‚àà c2), s1 ‚àà c3)
  adantld(c4 ‚àà USGraph, { s1, c6 } ‚àà c2, { s0, s1 } ‚àà c2, s1 ‚àà c3)
  syl(c4 ‚àà USGraph, ({ s0, s1 } ‚àà c2 ‚Üí s1 ‚àà c3), c4 ‚àà UMGraph)
  usgrumgr(c4)
  ex(c4 ‚àà UMGraph, { s0, s1 } ‚àà c2, s1 ‚àà c3)
  simprd((c4 ‚àà UMGraph ‚àß { s0, s1 } ‚àà c2), s1 ‚àà c3, s0 ‚àà c3)
  umgrpredgv(c4, s0, s1, c2, c3)
  anbi2i(s1 ‚àà c3, { { s0, s1 }, { s1, c6 } } ‚äÜ c2, ({ s1, c6 } ‚àà c2 ‚àß { s0, s1 } ‚àà c2))
  bitr3i({ { s0, s1 }, { s1, c6 } } ‚äÜ c2, ({ s1, c6 } ‚àà c2 ‚àß { s0, s1 } ‚àà c2), ({ s0, s1 } ‚àà c2 ‚àß { s1, c6 } ‚àà c2))
  prss({ s0, s1 }, c2, { s1, c6 })
  prex(s0, s1)
  prex(s1, c6)
  ancom({ s0, s1 } ‚àà c2, { s1, c6 } ‚àà c2)
  anbi1d(c4 ‚àà USGraph, { s1, c6 } ‚àà c2, { s0, s1 } ‚àà c2, s1 ‚àà c1)
  syl5rbb(c4 ‚àà USGraph, { s1, c6 } ‚àà c2, s1 ‚àà c1, s1 ‚àà(c4[NeighbVtx]c6))
  eleq2i(s1, c1, (c4[NeighbVtx]c6))
  nbusgreledg(c4, s1, c6, c2)
  df-reu(s1, c3, { { s0, s1 }, { s1, c6 } } ‚äÜ c2)

blocks.name: frgrncvvdeqlem8
blocks.content: Lemma 8 for ~ frgrncvvdeq . This corresponds to statement 2 in [Huneke] p. 1: "The map is one-to-one since z in N(x) is uniquely determined as the common neighbor of x and a(x)". (Contributed by Alexander van der Vekens, 23-Dec-2017.) (Revised by AV, 10-May-2021.) (Revised by AV, 30-Dec-2021.)

blocks.content: Lemma 9 for ~ frgrncvvdeq . This corresponds to statement 3 in [Huneke] p. 1: "By symmetry the map is onto". (Contributed by Alexander van der Vekens, 24-Dec-2017.) (Revised by AV, 10-May-2021.) (Proof shortened by AV, 12-Feb-2022.)

  ‚ä£ c0 =(s0 ‚àà c1 ‚Ü¶ iota(s1 ‚àà c2, { s0, s1 } ‚àà c5))

blocks.name: frgrncvvdeq
blocks.content: In a friendship graph, two vertices which are not connected by an edge have the same degree. This corresponds to claim 1 in [Huneke] p. 1: "If x,y are elements of (the friendship graph) G and are not adjacent, then they have the same degree (i.e., the same number of adjacent vertices).". (Contributed by Alexander van der Vekens, 19-Dec-2017.) (Revised by AV, 10-May-2021.)

blocks.name: frgrwopreglem4a
blocks.content: In a friendship graph any two vertices with different degrees are connected. Alternate version of ~ frgrwopreglem4 without a fixed degree and without using the sets ` A ` and ` B ` . (Contributed by Alexander van der Vekens, 30-Dec-2017.) (Revised by AV, 4-Feb-2022.)

thm frgrwopreglem4a(class c0, class c1, class c2, class c3, class c4, class c5) {
  |- wi(w3a(wcel(c0, cfrgr), wa(wcel(c1, c2), wcel(c3, c2)), wne(cfv(c4, c1), cfv(c4, c3))), wcel(cpr(c1, c3), c5))
  -| wceq(c2, cfv(cvtx, c0))
  -| wceq(c4, cfv(cvtxdg, c0))

} = {

blocks.name: frgrwopreglem5a
blocks.content: If a friendship graph has two vertices with the same degree and two other vertices with different degrees, then there is a 4-cycle in the graph. Alternate version of ~ frgrwopreglem5 without a fixed degree and without using the sets ` A ` and ` B ` . (Contributed by Alexander van der Vekens, 31-Dec-2017.) (Revised by AV, 4-Feb-2022.)

blocks.name: frgrwopreglem1
blocks.content: Lemma 1 for ~ frgrwopreg : the classes ` A ` and ` B ` are sets. The definition of ` A ` and ` B ` corresponds to definition 3 in [Huneke] p. 2: "Let A be the set of all vertices of degree k, let B be the set of all vertices of degree different from k, ..." (Contributed by Alexander van der Vekens, 31-Dec-2017.) (Revised by AV, 10-May-2021.)

  -| wceq(c4, cfv(cvtxdg, c3))
  -| wceq(c0, crab(s0, c2, wceq(cfv(c4, cv(s0)), c5)))
  -| wceq(c1, cdif(c2, c0))
  -| diffsc(s0, c2)
} = {
  a1ii(wa(wcel(c0, universe), wcel(c1, universe)), wceq(c4, cfv(cvtxdg, c3)))
  ax-mp(wa(wcel(c0, universe), wcel(c1, universe)), wcel(c2, universe))
  fvexi(c2, cvtx, c3)
  jca(wcel(c2, universe), wcel(c0, universe), wcel(c1, universe))
  syl5eqel(c0, universe, crab(s0, c2, wceq(cfv(c4, cv(s0)), c5)), wcel(c2, universe))

  syl5eqel(c1, universe, cdif(c2, c0), wcel(c2, universe))

}

blocks.name: frgrwopreglem2
blocks.content: Lemma 2 for ~ frgrwopreg . If the set ` A ` of vertices of degree ` K ` is not empty in a friendship graph with at least two vertices, then ` K ` must be greater than 1 . This is only an observation, which is not required for the proof the friendship theorem. (Contributed by Alexander van der Vekens, 30-Dec-2017.) (Revised by AV, 2-Jan-2022.)

blocks.name: frgrwopreglem4
blocks.content: Lemma 4 for ~ frgrwopreg . In a friendship graph each vertex with degree ` K ` is connected with any vertex with degree other than ` K ` . This corresponds to statement 4 in [Huneke] p. 2: "By the first claim, every vertex in A is adjacent to every vertex in B.". (Contributed by Alexander van der Vekens, 30-Dec-2017.) (Revised by AV, 10-May-2021.) (Proof shortened by AV, 4-Feb-2022.)

blocks.name: frgrwopregasn
blocks.content: According to statement 5 in [Huneke] p. 2: "If A ... is a singleton, then that singleton is a universal friend". This version of ~ frgrwopreg1 is stricter (claiming that the singleton itself is a universal friend instead of claiming the existence of a universal friend only) and therefore closer to Huneke's statement. This strict variant, however, is not required for the proof of the friendship theorem. (Contributed by Alexander van der Vekens, 1-Jan-2018.) (Revised by AV, 4-Feb-2022.)

blocks.name: frgrwopregbsn
blocks.content: According to statement 5 in [Huneke] p. 2: "If ... B is a singleton, then that singleton is a universal friend". This version of ~ frgrwopreg2 is stricter (claiming that the singleton itself is a universal friend instead of claiming the existence of a universal friend only) and therefore closer to Huneke's statement. This strict variant, however, is not required for the proof of the friendship theorem. (Contributed by AV, 4-Feb-2022.)

blocks.name: frgrwopreglem5
blocks.content: Lemma 5 for ~ frgrwopreg . If ` A ` as well as ` B ` contain at least two vertices, there is a 4-cycle in a friendship graph. This corresponds to statement 6 in [Huneke] p. 2: "... otherwise, there are two different vertices in A, and they have two common neighbors in B, ...". (Contributed by Alexander van der Vekens, 31-Dec-2017.) (Proof shortened by AV, 5-Feb-2022.)

blocks.name: frgrwopreg
blocks.content: In a friendship graph there are either no vertices ( ` A = (/) ` ) or exactly one vertex ( ` ( # `` A ) = 1 ` ) having degree ` K ` , or all ( ` B = (/) ` ) or all except one vertices ( ` ( # `` B ) = 1 ` ) have degree ` K ` . (Contributed by Alexander van der Vekens, 31-Dec-2017.) (Revised by AV, 10-May-2021.) (Proof shortened by AV, 3-Jan-2022.)

blocks.name: frgrregorufr0
blocks.content: In a friendship graph there are either no vertices having degree ` K ` , or all vertices have degree ` K ` for any (nonnegative integer) ` K ` , unless there is a universal friend. This corresponds to claim 2 in [Huneke] p. 2: "... all vertices have degree k, unless there is a universal friend." (Contributed by Alexander van der Vekens, 1-Jan-2018.) (Revised by AV, 11-May-2021.) (Proof shortened by AV, 3-Jan-2022.)

blocks.name: frgrregorufr
blocks.content: If there is a vertex having degree ` K ` for each (nonnegative integer) ` K ` in a friendship graph, then either all vertices have degree ` K ` or there is a universal friend. This corresponds to claim 2 in [Huneke] p. 2: "Suppose there is a vertex of degree k > 1. ... all vertices have degree k, unless there is a universal friend. ... It follows that G is k-regular, i.e., the degree of every vertex is k". (Contributed by Alexander van der Vekens, 1-Jan-2018.)

blocks.name: frgrregorufrg
blocks.content: If there is a vertex having degree ` k ` for each nonnegative integer ` k ` in a friendship graph, then there is a universal friend. This corresponds to claim 2 in [Huneke] p. 2: "Suppose there is a vertex of degree k > 1. ... all vertices have degree k, unless there is a universal friend. ... It follows that G is k-regular, i.e., the degree of every vertex is k". Variant of ~ frgrregorufr with generalization. (Contributed by Alexander van der Vekens, 6-Sep-2018.) (Revised by AV, 26-May-2021.) (Proof shortened by AV, 12-Jan-2022.)

blocks.name: frgr2wsp1
blocks.content: In a friendship graph, there is exactly one simple path of length 2 between two different vertices. (Contributed by Alexander van der Vekens, 3-Mar-2018.) (Revised by AV, 13-May-2021.)

blocks.name: frgr2wwlkeqm
blocks.content: If there is a (simple) path of length 2 from one vertex to another vertex and a (simple) path of length 2 from the other vertex back to the first vertex in a friendship graph, then the middle vertex is the same. This is only an observation, which is not required to proof the friendship theorem. (Contributed by Alexander van der Vekens, 20-Feb-2018.) (Revised by AV, 13-May-2021.) (Proof shortened by AV, 7-Jan-2022.)
blocks.origin:

blocks.name: frgrhash2wsp
blocks.content: The number of simple paths of length 2 is n*(n-1) in a friendship graph with n vertices. This corresponds to the proof of claim 3 in [Huneke] p. 2: "... the paths of length two in G: by assumption there are ( n 2 ) such paths.". However, Huneke counts undirected paths, so obtains the result ( ` ( n _C 2 ) = ( ( n x. ( n - 1 ) ) / 2 ) ` ), whereas we count directed paths, obtaining twice that number. (Contributed by Alexander van der Vekens, 6-Mar-2018.) (Revised by AV, 10-Jan-2022.)
blocks.origin:

blocks.name: fusgr2wsp2nb
blocks.content: The set of paths of length 2 with a given vertex in the middle for a finite simple graph is the union of all paths of length 2 from one neighbor to another neighbor of this vertex via this vertex. (Contributed by Alexander van der Vekens, 9-Mar-2018.) (Revised by AV, 17-May-2021.) (Proof shortened by AV, 16-Mar-2022.)

blocks.name: fusgreghash2wspv
blocks.content: According to statement 7 in [Huneke] p. 2: "For each vertex v, there are exactly ( k 2 ) paths with length two having v in the middle, ..." in a finite k-regular graph. For directed simple paths of length 2 represented by length 3 strings, we have again k*(k-1) such paths, see also comment of ~ frgrhash2wsp . (Contributed by Alexander van der Vekens, 10-Mar-2018.) (Revised by AV, 17-May-2021.) (Proof shortened by AV, 12-Feb-2022.)
blocks.origin:
thm fusgreghash2wspv(setvar s0, setvar s1, setvar s2, class c0, class c1, class c2, class c3) {
  |- wi(wcel(c0, cfusgr), wral(s0, c1, wi(wceq(cfv(cfv(cvtxdg, c0), cv(s0)), c2), wceq(cfv(chash, cfv(c3, cv(s0))), co(c2, cmul, co(c2, cmin, nat1))))))
  -| wceq(c1, cfv(cvtx, c0))
  -| wceq(c3, cmpt(s1, c1, crab(s2, co(nat2, cwwspthsn, c0), wceq(cfv(cv(s2), nat1), cv(s1)))))
  -| diffss(s0, s1)
  -| diffss(s0, s2)
  -| diffss(s1, s2)
  -| diffsc(s0, c0)
  -| diffsc(s1, c0)
  -| diffsc(s1, c1)
  -| diffsc(s2, c0)
} = {
  ralrimiva(s0, c1, wcel(c0, cfusgr), wi(wceq(cfv(cfv(cvtxdg, c0), cv(s0)), c2), wceq(cfv(chash, cfv(c3, cv(s0))), co(c2, cmul, co(c2, cmin, nat1)))))
  ex(wa(wcel(c0, cfusgr), wcel(cv(s0), c1)), wceq(cfv(cfv(cvtxdg, c0), cv(s0)), c2), wceq(cfv(chash, cfv(c3, cv(s0))), co(c2, cmul, co(c2, cmin, nat1))))

blocks.name: fusgreg2wsp

blocks.name: fusgreghash2wsp
blocks.content: In a finite k-regular graph with N vertices there are N times "k choose 2" paths with length 2, according to statement 8 in [Huneke] p. 2: "... giving n * ( k 2 ) total paths of length two.", if the direction of traversing the path is not respected. For simple paths of length 2 represented by length 3 strings, however, we have again n*k*(k-1) such paths. (Contributed by Alexander van der Vekens, 11-Mar-2018.) (Revised by AV, 19-May-2021.) (Proof shortened by AV, 12-Jan-2022.)

blocks.name: frrusgrord0
blocks.content: If a nonempty finite friendship graph is k-regular, its order is k(k-1)+1. This corresponds to claim 3 in [Huneke] p. 2: "Next we claim that the number n of vertices in G is exactly k(k-1)+1.". (Contributed by Alexander van der Vekens, 11-Mar-2018.) (Revised by AV, 26-May-2021.) (Proof shortened by AV, 12-Jan-2022.)
blocks.origin:
thm frrusgrord0(setvar s0, class c0, class c1, class c2) {

  -| wceq(c1, cfv(cvtx, c0))
  -| diffsc(s0, c0)
  -| diffsc(s0, c1)
  -| diffsc(s0, c2)
} = {
  ex(w3a(wcel(c0, cfrgr), wcel(c1, cfn), wne(c1, emptycls)), wral(s0, c1, wceq(cfv(cfv(cvtxdg, c0), cv(s0)), c2)), wceq(cfv(chash, c1), co(co(c2, cmul, co(c2, cmin, nat1)), caddc, nat1)))

blocks.name: frrusgrord
blocks.content: If a nonempty finite friendship graph is k-regular, its order is k(k-1)+1. This corresponds to claim 3 in [Huneke] p. 2: "Next we claim that the number n of vertices in G is exactly k(k-1)+1.". Variant of ~ frrusgrord0 , using the definition ` RegUSGraph ` ( ~ df-rusgr ). (Contributed by Alexander van der Vekens, 25-Aug-2018.) (Revised by AV, 26-May-2021.) (Proof shortened by AV, 12-Jan-2022.)
blocks.origin:
thm frrusgrord(class c0, class c1, class c2) {
  |- wi(wa(wcel(c0, cfn), wne(c0, emptycls)), wi(wa(wcel(c1, cfrgr), wbr(c1, crusgr, c2)), wceq(cfv(chash, c0), co(co(c2, cmul, co(c2, cmin, nat1)), caddc, nat1))))
  -| wceq(c0, cfv(cvtx, c1))
} = {
  impd(wa(wcel(c0, cfn), wne(c0, emptycls)), wcel(c1, cfrgr), wbr(c1, crusgr, c2), wceq(cfv(chash, c0), co(co(c2, cmul, co(c2, cmin, nat1)), caddc, nat1)))
  expcom(wa(wcel(c0, cfn), wne(c0, emptycls)), wcel(c1, cfrgr), wi(wbr(c1, crusgr, c2), wceq(cfv(chash, c0), co(co(c2, cmul, co(c2, cmin, nat1)), caddc, nat1))))
  3expb(wcel(c1, cfrgr), wcel(c0, cfn), wne(c0, emptycls), wi(wbr(c1, crusgr, c2), wceq(cfv(chash, c0), co(co(c2, cmul, co(c2, cmin, nat1)), caddc, nat1))))
  syl5(w3a(wcel(c1, cfrgr), wcel(c0, cfn), wne(c0, emptycls)), wbr(c1, crusgr, c2), wceq(cfv(chash, c0), co(co(c2, cmul, co(c2, cmin, nat1)), caddc, nat1)), wral(hs0, c0, wceq(cfv(cfv(cvtxdg, c1), cv(hs0)), c2)))
  simprd(wbr(c1, crusgr, c2), wral(hs0, c0, wceq(cfv(cfv(cvtxdg, c1), cv(hs0)), c2)), wcel(c2, cxnn0))
  syl(wbr(c1, crusgr, c2), wa(wcel(c2, cxnn0), wral(hs0, c0, wceq(cfv(cfv(cvtxdg, c1), cv(hs0)), c2))), wbr(c1, crgr, c2))
  rusgrrgr(c1, c2)

blocks.name: clwwnrepclwwn
blocks.content: If the initial vertex of a closed walk occurs another time in the walk, the walk starts with a closed walk. Notice that ` 3 <_ N ` is required, because for ` N = 2 ` , ` ( w prefix ( N - 2 ) ) = ( w prefix 0 ) = (/) ` , but ` (/) ` (and anything else) is not a representation of an empty closed walk as word, see ~ clwwlkn0 . (Contributed by Alexander van der Vekens, 15-Sep-2018.) (Revised by AV, 28-May-2021.) (Revised by AV, 30-Oct-2022.)
blocks.origin:
thm clwwnrepclwwn(class c0, class c1, class c2) {
  |- wi(w3a(wcel(c0, cfv(cuz, nat3)), wcel(c1, co(c0, cclwwlkn, c2)), wceq(cfv(c1, co(c0, cmin, nat2)), cfv(c1, nat0))), wcel(co(c1, cpfx, co(c0, cmin, nat2)), co(co(c0, cmin, nat2), cclwwlkn, c2)))
} = {
  syl3anc(w3a(wcel(c0, cfv(cuz, nat3)), wcel(c1, co(c0, cclwwlkn, c2)), wceq(cfv(c1, co(c0, cmin, nat2)), cfv(c1, nat0))), wcel(co(c1, cpfx, co(c0, cmin, nat2)), co(co(c0, cmin, nat2), cclwwlkn, c2)), wa(wcel(co(c0, cmin, nat2), cn), wcel(co(c0, cmin, nat1), cfv(cuz, co(c0, cmin, nat2)))), wcel(c1, co(co(c0, cmin, nat1), cwwlksn, c2)), wceq(cfv(c1, co(c0, cmin, nat2)), cfv(c1, nat0)))
  3ad2ant1(wcel(c0, cfv(cuz, nat3)), wcel(c1, co(c0, cclwwlkn, c2)), wceq(cfv(c1, co(c0, cmin, nat2)), cfv(c1, nat0)), wa(wcel(co(c0, cmin, nat2), cn), wcel(co(c0, cmin, nat1), cfv(cuz, co(c0, cmin, nat2)))))
  jca(wcel(c0, cfv(cuz, nat3)), wcel(co(c0, cmin, nat2), cn), wcel(co(c0, cmin, nat1), cfv(cuz, co(c0, cmin, nat2))))
  uz3m2nn(c0)
  sylancl(wcel(c0, cfv(cuz, nat3)), wcel(co(c0, cmin, nat1), cfv(cuz, co(c0, cmin, nat2))), wcel(c0, cz), wcel(nat2, cfv(cuz, nat1)))
  eluzelz(c0, nat3)
  2eluzge1()
  subeluzsub(c0, nat2, nat1)
  3ad2ant2(wcel(c0, cfv(cuz, nat3)), wcel(c1, co(c0, cclwwlkn, c2)), wceq(cfv(c1, co(c0, cmin, nat2)), cfv(c1, nat0)), wcel(c1, co(co(c0, cmin, nat1), cwwlksn, c2)))
  clwwlknwwlksn(c1, c0, c2)
  simp3(wcel(c0, cfv(cuz, nat3)), wcel(c1, co(c0, cclwwlkn, c2)), wceq(cfv(c1, co(c0, cmin, nat2)), cfv(c1, nat0)))
  clwwlkinwwlk(co(c0, cmin, nat2), co(c0, cmin, nat1), c1, c2)
}

blocks.name: 2clwwlk
blocks.content: Value of operation ` C ` , mapping a vertex v and an integer n greater than 1 to the "closed n-walks v(0) ... v(n-2) v(n-1) v(n) from v = v(0) = v(n) with v(n-2) = v" according to definition 6 in [Huneke] p. 2. Such closed walks are "double loops" consisting of a closed (n-2)-walk v = v(0) ... v(n-2) = v and a closed 2-walk v = v(n-2) v(n-1) v(n) = v, see ~ 2clwwlk2clwwlk . ` ( X C N ) ` is called the "set of double loops of length ` N ` on vertex ` X ` " in the following. (Contributed by Alexander van der Vekens, 14-Sep-2018.) (Revised by AV, 29-May-2021.) (Revised by AV, 20-Apr-2022.)

blocks.name: 2clwwlk2
blocks.content: The set ` ( X C 2 ) ` of double loops of length 2 on a vertex ` X ` is equal to the set of closed walks with length 2 on ` X ` . Considered as "double loops", the first of the two closed walks/loops is degenerated, i.e., has length 0. (Contributed by AV, 18-Feb-2022.) (Revised by AV, 20-Apr-2022.)

blocks.name: extwwlkfab
blocks.content: The set ` ( X C N ) ` of double loops of length ` N ` on vertex ` X ` can be constructed from the set ` F ` of closed walks on ` X ` with length smaller by 2 than the fixed length by appending a neighbor of the last vertex and afterwards the last vertex (which is the first vertex) itself ("walking forth and back" from the last vertex). ` 3 <_ N ` is required since for ` N = 2 ` : ` F = ( X ( ClWWalksNOn `` G ) 0 ) ` ` = (/) ` (see ~ clwwlk0on0 stating that a closed walk of length 0 is not represented as word), which would result in an empty set on the right hand side, but ` ( X C N ) ` needs not be empty, see ~ 2clwwlk2 . (Contributed by Alexander van der Vekens, 18-Sep-2018.) (Revised by AV, 29-May-2021.) (Revised by AV, 31-Oct-2022.)

blocks.name: extwwlkfabel
blocks.content: Characterization of an element of the set ` ( X C N ) ` , i.e., a double loop of length ` N ` on vertex ` X ` with a construction from the set ` F ` of closed walks on ` X ` with length smaller by 2 than the fixed length by appending a neighbor of the last vertex and afterwards the last vertex (which is the first vertex) itself ("walking forth and back" from the last vertex). (Contributed by AV, 22-Feb-2022.) (Revised by AV, 31-Oct-2022.)
blocks.origin:
thm extwwlkfabel(setvar s0, setvar s1, setvar s2, class c0, class c1, class c2, class c3, class c4, class c5, class c6) {
  |- wi(w3a(wcel(c0, cusgr), wcel(c1, c2), wcel(c3, cfv(cuz, nat3))), wb(wcel(c4, co(c1, c5, c3)), wa(wcel(c4, co(c3, cclwwlkn, c0)), w3a(wcel(co(c4, cpfx, co(c3, cmin, nat2)), c6), wcel(cfv(c4, co(c3, cmin, nat1)), co(c0, cnbgr, c1)), wceq(cfv(c4, co(c3, cmin, nat2)), c1)))))
  -| wceq(c2, cfv(cvtx, c0))
  -| wceq(c5, cmpo(s0, s1, c2, cfv(cuz, nat2), crab(s2, co(cv(s0), cfv(cclwwlknon, c0), cv(s1)), wceq(cfv(cv(s2), co(cv(s1), cmin, nat2)), cv(s0)))))
  -| wceq(c6, co(c1, cfv(cclwwlknon, c0), co(c3, cmin, nat2)))
  -| diffss(s0, s1)
  -| diffss(s0, s2)
  -| diffss(s1, s2)
  -| diffsc(s0, c0)
  -| diffsc(s0, c1)
  -| diffsc(s0, c2)
  -| diffsc(s0, c3)
  -| diffsc(s1, c0)
  -| diffsc(s1, c1)
  -| diffsc(s1, c2)
  -| diffsc(s1, c3)
  -| diffsc(s2, c0)
  -| diffsc(s2, c1)
  -| diffsc(s2, c2)
  -| diffsc(s2, c3)
  -| diffsc(s2, c4)
  -| diffsc(s2, c6)
} = {
  syl6bb(w3a(wcel(c0, cusgr), wcel(c1, c2), wcel(c3, cfv(cuz, nat3))), wcel(c4, co(c1, c5, c3)), wa(wcel(c4, co(c3, cclwwlkn, c0)), w3a(wcel(co(c4, cpfx, co(c3, cmin, nat2)), c6), wcel(cfv(c4, co(c3, cmin, nat1)), co(c0, cnbgr, c1)), wceq(cfv(c4, co(c3, cmin, nat2)), c1))), wcel(c4, crab(s2, co(c3, cclwwlkn, c0), w3a(wcel(co(cv(s2), cpfx, co(c3, cmin, nat2)), c6), wcel(cfv(cv(s2), co(c3, cmin, nat1)), co(c0, cnbgr, c1)), wceq(cfv(cv(s2), co(c3, cmin, nat2)), c1)))))
  eleq2d(c4, co(c1, c5, c3), crab(s2, co(c3, cclwwlkn, c0), w3a(wcel(co(cv(s2), cpfx, co(c3, cmin, nat2)), c6), wcel(cfv(cv(s2), co(c3, cmin, nat1)), co(c0, cnbgr, c1)), wceq(cfv(cv(s2), co(c3, cmin, nat2)), c1))), w3a(wcel(c0, cusgr), wcel(c1, c2), wcel(c3, cfv(cuz, nat3))))
  extwwlkfab(s2, s0, s1, c0, c1, c2, c3, c5, c6)
  elrab(s2, c4, co(c3, cclwwlkn, c0), w3a(wcel(co(cv(s2), cpfx, co(c3, cmin, nat2)), c6), wcel(cfv(cv(s2), co(c3, cmin, nat1)), co(c0, cnbgr, c1)), wceq(cfv(cv(s2), co(c3, cmin, nat2)), c1)), w3a(wcel(co(c4, cpfx, co(c3, cmin, nat2)), c6), wcel(cfv(c4, co(c3, cmin, nat1)), co(c0, cnbgr, c1)), wceq(cfv(c4, co(c3, cmin, nat2)), c1)))
  3anbi123d(wceq(cv(s2), c4), wcel(co(cv(s2), cpfx, co(c3, cmin, nat2)), c6), wcel(cfv(cv(s2), co(c3, cmin, nat1)), co(c0, cnbgr, c1)), wceq(cfv(cv(s2), co(c3, cmin, nat2)), c1), wcel(co(c4, cpfx, co(c3, cmin, nat2)), c6), wcel(cfv(c4, co(c3, cmin, nat1)), co(c0, cnbgr, c1)), wceq(cfv(c4, co(c3, cmin, nat2)), c1))
  eleq1d(co(cv(s2), cpfx, co(c3, cmin, nat2)), c6, co(c4, cpfx, co(c3, cmin, nat2)), wceq(cv(s2), c4))
  oveq1(cv(s2), c4, cpfx, co(c3, cmin, nat2))
  eleq1d(cfv(cv(s2), co(c3, cmin, nat1)), co(c0, cnbgr, c1), cfv(c4, co(c3, cmin, nat1)), wceq(cv(s2), c4))
  fveq1(cv(s2), c4, co(c3, cmin, nat1))
  eqeq1d(cfv(cv(s2), co(c3, cmin, nat2)), c1, cfv(c4, co(c3, cmin, nat2)), wceq(cv(s2), c4))
  fveq1(cv(s2), c4, co(c3, cmin, nat2))
  diffss.ex(s2, s0)
  diffss.ex(s2, s1)
  diff.co.s(s2, c3, cclwwlkn, c0)
  diff.cclwwlkn.s(s2)
  diff.w3a.s(s2, wcel(co(c4, cpfx, co(c3, cmin, nat2)), c6), wcel(cfv(c4, co(c3, cmin, nat1)), co(c0, cnbgr, c1)), wceq(cfv(c4, co(c3, cmin, nat2)), c1))
  diff.wcel.s(s2, co(c4, cpfx, co(c3, cmin, nat2)), c6)
  diff.co.s(s2, c4, cpfx, co(c3, cmin, nat2))
  diff.cpfx.s(s2)
  diff.wcel.s(s2, cfv(c4, co(c3, cmin, nat1)), co(c0, cnbgr, c1))
  diff.cfv.s(s2, c4, co(c3, cmin, nat1))
  diff.co.s(s2, c3, cmin, nat1)
  diff.nat1.s(s2)
  diff.co.s(s2, c0, cnbgr, c1)
  diff.cnbgr.s(s2)
  diff.wceq.s(s2, cfv(c4, co(c3, cmin, nat2)), c1)
  diff.cfv.s(s2, c4, co(c3, cmin, nat2))
  diff.co.s(s2, c3, cmin, nat2)
  diff.cmin.s(s2)
  diff.nat2.s(s2)
}

  ‚ä¢ ((c0 ‚àà USGraph ‚àß c1 ‚àà c2 ‚àß c3 ‚àà(‚Ñ§‚â• ` 3))‚Üí(c4 ‚àà(c1[c5]c3)‚Üî(c4 ‚àà(c3[ClWWalksN]c0)‚àß((c4[prefix](c3[-]2))‚àà c6 ‚àß(c4 `(c3[-]1))‚àà(c0[NeighbVtx]c1)‚àß(c4 `(c3[-]2))= c1))))
  ‚ä£ c2 =(Vtx ` c0)
  ‚ä£ c5 =(s0 ‚àà c2, s1 ‚àà(‚Ñ§‚â• ` 2)‚Ü¶ { s2 ‚àà(s0[(ClWWalksNOn ` c0)]s1)|(s2 `(s1[-]2))= s0 })

} = {
  syl6bb((c0 ‚àà USGraph ‚àß c1 ‚àà c2 ‚àß c3 ‚àà(‚Ñ§‚â• ` 3)), c4 ‚àà(c1[c5]c3), (c4 ‚àà(c3[ClWWalksN]c0)‚àß((c4[prefix](c3[-]2))‚àà c6 ‚àß(c4 `(c3[-]1))‚àà(c0[NeighbVtx]c1)‚àß(c4 `(c3[-]2))= c1)), c4 ‚àà { s2 ‚àà(c3[ClWWalksN]c0)|((s2[prefix](c3[-]2))‚àà c6 ‚àß(s2 `(c3[-]1))‚àà(c0[NeighbVtx]c1)‚àß(s2 `(c3[-]2))= c1)})
  eleq2d(c4, (c1[c5]c3), { s2 ‚àà(c3[ClWWalksN]c0)|((s2[prefix](c3[-]2))‚àà c6 ‚àß(s2 `(c3[-]1))‚àà(c0[NeighbVtx]c1)‚àß(s2 `(c3[-]2))= c1)}, (c0 ‚àà USGraph ‚àß c1 ‚àà c2 ‚àß c3 ‚àà(‚Ñ§‚â• ` 3)))
  extwwlkfab(s2, s0, s1, c0, c1, c2, c3, c5, c6)
  elrab(s2, c4, (c3[ClWWalksN]c0), ((s2[prefix](c3[-]2))‚àà c6 ‚àß(s2 `(c3[-]1))‚àà(c0[NeighbVtx]c1)‚àß(s2 `(c3[-]2))= c1), ((c4[prefix](c3[-]2))‚àà c6 ‚àß(c4 `(c3[-]1))‚àà(c0[NeighbVtx]c1)‚àß(c4 `(c3[-]2))= c1))
  3anbi123d(s2 = c4, (s2[prefix](c3[-]2))‚àà c6, (s2 `(c3[-]1))‚àà(c0[NeighbVtx]c1), (s2 `(c3[-]2))= c1, (c4[prefix](c3[-]2))‚àà c6, (c4 `(c3[-]1))‚àà(c0[NeighbVtx]c1), (c4 `(c3[-]2))= c1)

blocks.name: extwwlkfabelOLD
blocks.content: Obsolete version of ~ extwwlkfabel as of 12-Oct-2022. (Contributed by AV, 22-Feb-2022.) (Revised by AV, 5-Mar-2022.) (New usage is discouraged.) (Proof modification is discouraged.)
blocks.origin:
thm extwwlkfabelOLD(setvar s0, setvar s1, setvar s2, class c0, class c1, class c2, class c3, class c4, class c5, class c6) {
  |- wi(w3a(wcel(c0, cusgr), wcel(c1, c2), wcel(c3, cfv(cuz, nat3))), wb(wcel(c4, co(c1, c5, c3)), wa(wcel(c4, co(c3, cclwwlkn, c0)), w3a(wcel(co(c4, csubstr, cop(nat0, co(c3, cmin, nat2))), c6), wcel(cfv(c4, co(c3, cmin, nat1)), co(c0, cnbgr, c1)), wceq(cfv(c4, co(c3, cmin, nat2)), c1)))))
  -| wceq(c2, cfv(cvtx, c0))
  -| wceq(c5, cmpo(s0, s1, c2, cfv(cuz, nat2), crab(s2, co(cv(s0), cfv(cclwwlknon, c0), cv(s1)), wceq(cfv(cv(s2), co(cv(s1), cmin, nat2)), cv(s0)))))
  -| wceq(c6, co(c1, cfv(cclwwlknon, c0), co(c3, cmin, nat2)))

blocks.name: numclwwlk1lem2foa
blocks.content: Going forth and back from the end of a (closed) walk: ` W ` represents the closed walk p_0, ..., p_(n-2), p_0 = p_(n-2). With ` X ` = p_(n-2) = p_0 and ` Y ` = p_(n-1), ` ( ( W ++ <" X "> ) ++ <" Y "> ) ` represents the closed walk p_0, ..., p_(n-2), p_(n-1), p_n = p_0 which is a double loop of length ` N ` on vertex ` X ` . (Contributed by Alexander van der Vekens, 22-Sep-2018.) (Revised by AV, 29-May-2021.) (Revised by AV, 5-Mar-2022.) (Proof shortened by AV, 2-Nov-2022.)

blocks.content: ` T ` is a function, mapping a double loop of length ` N ` on vertex ` X ` to the ordered pair of the first loop and the successor of ` X ` in the second loop, which must be a neighbor of ` X ` . (Contributed by Alexander van der Vekens, 19-Sep-2018.) (Revised by AV, 29-May-2021.) (Proof shortened by AV, 23-Feb-2022.) (Revised by AV, 31-Oct-2022.)

blocks.content: The set of double loops of length ` N ` on vertex ` X ` and the set of closed walks of length less by 2 on ` X ` combined with the neighbors of ` X ` are equinumerous. (Contributed by Alexander van der Vekens, 6-Jul-2018.) (Revised by AV, 29-May-2021.) (Revised by AV, 31-Jul-2022.) (Proof shortened by AV, 3-Nov-2022.)

blocks.name: numclwwlk1
blocks.content: Statement 9 in [Huneke] p. 2: "If n > 1, then the number of closed n-walks v(0) ... v(n-2) v(n-1) v(n) from v = v(0) = v(n) with v(n-2) = v is kf(n-2)". Since ` G ` is k-regular, the vertex v(n-2) = v has k neighbors v(n-1), so there are k walks from v(n-2) = v to v(n) = v (via each of v's neighbors) completing each of the f(n-2) walks from v=v(0) to v(n-2)=v. This theorem holds even for k=0, but not for n=2, since ` F = (/) ` , but ` ( X C 2 ) ` , the set of closed walks with length 2 on ` X ` , see ~ 2clwwlk2 , needs not be ` (/) ` in this case. This is because of the special definition of ` F ` and the usage of words to represent (closed) walks, and does not contradict Huneke's statement, which would read "the number of closed 2-walks v(0) v(1) v(2) from v = v(0) = v(2) ... is kf(0)", where f(0)=1 is the number of empty closed walks on v, see ~ numclwlk1lem1 . If the general representation of (closed) walk is used, Huneke's statement can be proven even for n = 2, see ~ numclwlk1 . This case, however, is not required to prove the friendship theorem. (Contributed by Alexander van der Vekens, 26-Sep-2018.) (Revised by AV, 29-May-2021.) (Revised by AV, 6-Mar-2022.) (Proof shortened by AV, 31-Jul-2022.)

blocks.name: clwwlknonclwlknonen
blocks.content: The sets of the two representations of closed walks of a fixed positive length on a fixed vertex are equinumerous. (Contributed by AV, 27-May-2022.) (Proof shortened by AV, 3-Nov-2022.)

blocks.name: dlwwlknondlwlknonen
blocks.content: The sets of the two representations of double loops of a fixed length on a fixed vertex are equinumerous. (Contributed by AV, 30-May-2022.) (Proof shortened by AV, 3-Nov-2022.)

  -| wceq(c5, crab(s0, co(c1, cfv(cclwwlknon, c0), c3), wceq(cfv(cv(s0), co(c3, cmin, nat2)), c1)))

blocks.name: numclwlk1lem1
blocks.content: Lemma 1 for ~ numclwlk1 (Statement 9 in [Huneke] p. 2 for n=2): "the number of closed 2-walks v(0) v(1) v(2) from v = v(0) = v(2) ... is kf(0)". (Contributed by AV, 23-May-2022.)

  -| wceq(c0, cfv(cvtx, c1))
  -| wceq(c5, crab(s0, cfv(cclwlks, c1), w3a(wceq(cfv(chash, cfv(c1st, cv(s0))), c4), wceq(cfv(cfv(c2nd, cv(s0)), nat0), c3), wceq(cfv(cfv(c2nd, cv(s0)), co(c4, cmin, nat2)), c3))))
  -| wceq(c6, crab(s0, cfv(cclwlks, c1), wa(wceq(cfv(chash, cfv(c1st, cv(s0))), co(c4, cmin, nat2)), wceq(cfv(cfv(c2nd, cv(s0)), nat0), c3))))

blocks.name: numclwlk1
blocks.content: Statement 9 in [Huneke] p. 2: "If n > 1, then the number of closed n-walks v(0) ... v(n-2) v(n-1) v(n) from v = v(0) = v(n) with v(n-2) = v is kf(n-2)". Since ` G ` is k-regular, the vertex v(n-2) = v has k neighbors v(n-1), so there are k walks from v(n-2) = v to v(n) = v (via each of v's neighbors) completing each of the f(n-2) walks from v=v(0) to v(n-2)=v. This theorem holds even for k=0. (Contributed by AV, 23-May-2022.)
blocks.origin:
thm numclwlk1(setvar s0, class c0, class c1, class c2, class c3, class c4, class c5, class c6) {
  |- wi(wa(wa(wcel(c0, cfn), wbr(c1, crusgr, c2)), wa(wcel(c3, c0), wcel(c4, cfv(cuz, nat2)))), wceq(cfv(chash, c5), co(c2, cmul, cfv(chash, c6))))
  -| wceq(c0, cfv(cvtx, c1))
  -| wceq(c5, crab(s0, cfv(cclwlks, c1), w3a(wceq(cfv(chash, cfv(c1st, cv(s0))), c4), wceq(cfv(cfv(c2nd, cv(s0)), nat0), c3), wceq(cfv(cfv(c2nd, cv(s0)), co(c4, cmin, nat2)), c3))))
  -| wceq(c6, crab(s0, cfv(cclwlks, c1), wa(wceq(cfv(chash, cfv(c1st, cv(s0))), co(c4, cmin, nat2)), wceq(cfv(cfv(c2nd, cv(s0)), nat0), c3))))
  -| diffsc(s0, c0)
  -| diffsc(s0, c1)
  -| diffsc(s0, c2)
  -| diffsc(s0, c3)
  -| diffsc(s0, c4)
  -| diffsc(s0, c5)
  -| diffsc(s0, c6)
} = {
  impcom(wa(wcel(c0, cfn), wbr(c1, crusgr, c2)), wa(wcel(c3, c0), wcel(c4, cfv(cuz, nat2))), wceq(cfv(chash, c5), co(c2, cmul, cfv(chash, c6))))
  impcom(wcel(c3, c0), wcel(c4, cfv(cuz, nat2)), wi(wa(wcel(c0, cfn), wbr(c1, crusgr, c2)), wceq(cfv(chash, c5), co(c2, cmul, cfv(chash, c6)))))
  syl(wcel(c4, cfv(cuz, nat2)), wi(wcel(c3, c0), wi(wa(wcel(c0, cfn), wbr(c1, crusgr, c2)), wceq(cfv(chash, c5), co(c2, cmul, cfv(chash, c6))))), wo(wceq(c4, nat2), wcel(c4, cfv(cuz, co(nat2, caddc, nat1)))))
  uzp1(c4, nat2)
  jaoi(wceq(c4, nat2), wcel(c4, cfv(cuz, co(nat2, caddc, nat1))), wi(wcel(c3, c0), wi(wa(wcel(c0, cfn), wbr(c1, crusgr, c2)), wceq(cfv(chash, c5), co(c2, cmul, cfv(chash, c6))))))
  expcom(wceq(c4, nat2), wcel(c3, c0), wi(wa(wcel(c0, cfn), wbr(c1, crusgr, c2)), wceq(cfv(chash, c5), co(c2, cmul, cfv(chash, c6)))))
  expcom(wa(wcel(c3, c0), wceq(c4, nat2)), wa(wcel(c0, cfn), wbr(c1, crusgr, c2)), wceq(cfv(chash, c5), co(c2, cmul, cfv(chash, c6))))
  numclwlk1lem1(s0, c0, c1, c2, c3, c4, c5, c6)
  eleq2s(c4, cfv(cuz, co(nat2, caddc, nat1)), cfv(cuz, nat3), wi(wcel(c3, c0), wi(wa(wcel(c0, cfn), wbr(c1, crusgr, c2)), wceq(cfv(chash, c5), co(c2, cmul, cfv(chash, c6))))))
  expcom(wcel(c4, cfv(cuz, nat3)), wcel(c3, c0), wi(wa(wcel(c0, cfn), wbr(c1, crusgr, c2)), wceq(cfv(chash, c5), co(c2, cmul, cfv(chash, c6)))))
  expcom(wa(wcel(c3, c0), wcel(c4, cfv(cuz, nat3))), wa(wcel(c0, cfn), wbr(c1, crusgr, c2)), wceq(cfv(chash, c5), co(c2, cmul, cfv(chash, c6))))
  numclwlk1lem2(s0, c0, c1, c2, c3, c4, c5, c6)
  fveq2i(cuz, co(nat2, caddc, nat1), nat3)
  2p1e3()
}

blocks.name: numclwwlkovq
blocks.content: Value of operation ` Q ` , mapping a vertex ` v ` and a positive integer ` n ` to the not closed walks v(0) ... v(n) of length ` n ` from a fixed vertex ` v ` = v(0). "Not closed" means v(n) =/= v(0). Remark: ` n e. NN0 ` would not be useful: ~ numclwwlkqhash would not hold, because ` ( K ^ 0 ) = 1 ` ! (Contributed by Alexander van der Vekens, 27-Sep-2018.) (Revised by AV, 30-May-2021.)

blocks.name: numclwwlkqhash
blocks.content: In a ` K `-regular graph, the size of the set of walks of length ` N ` starting with a fixed vertex ` X ` and ending not at this vertex is the difference between ` K ` to the power of ` N ` and the size of the set of closed walks of length ` N ` on vertex ` X ` . (Contributed by Alexander van der Vekens, 30-Sep-2018.) (Revised by AV, 30-May-2021.) (Revised by AV, 5-Mar-2022.) (Proof shortened by AV, 7-Jul-2022.)

blocks.name: numclwwlk2lem1
blocks.content: In a friendship graph, for each walk of length ` n ` starting at a fixed vertex ` v ` and ending not at this vertex, there is a unique vertex so that the walk extended by an edge to this vertex and an edge from this vertex to the first vertex of the walk is a value of operation ` H ` . If the walk is represented as a word, it is sufficient to add one vertex to the word to obtain the closed walk contained in the value of operation ` H ` , since in a word representing a closed walk the starting vertex is not repeated at the end. This theorem generally holds only for friendship graphs, because these guarantee that for the first and last vertex there is a (unique) third vertex "in between". (Contributed by Alexander van der Vekens, 3-Oct-2018.) (Revised by AV, 30-May-2021.) (Revised by AV, 1-May-2022.)

blocks.name: numclwwlk2lem3
blocks.content: In a friendship graph, the size of the set of walks of length ` N ` starting with a fixed vertex ` X ` and ending not at this vertex equals the size of the set of all closed walks of length ` ( N + 2 ) ` starting at this vertex ` X ` and not having this vertex as last but 2 vertex. (Contributed by Alexander van der Vekens, 6-Oct-2018.) (Revised by AV, 31-May-2021.) (Proof shortened by AV, 3-Nov-2022.)

thm numclwwlk2lem3(setvar s0, setvar s1, setvar s2, class c0, class c1, class c2, class c3, class c4, class c5) {
  |- wi(w3a(wcel(c0, cfrgr), wcel(c1, c2), wcel(c3, cn)), wceq(cfv(chash, co(c1, c4, c3)), cfv(chash, co(c1, c5, co(c3, caddc, nat2)))))
  -| wceq(c2, cfv(cvtx, c0))
  -| wceq(c4, cmpo(s0, s1, c2, cn, crab(s2, co(cv(s1), cwwlksn, c0), wa(wceq(cfv(cv(s2), nat0), cv(s0)), wne(cfv(clsw, cv(s2)), cv(s0))))))
  -| wceq(c5, cmpo(s0, s1, c2, cfv(cuz, nat2), crab(s2, co(cv(s0), cfv(cclwwlknon, c0), cv(s1)), wne(cfv(cv(s2), co(cv(s1), cmin, nat2)), cv(s0)))))
  -| diffss(s0, s1)
  -| diffss(s0, s2)
  -| diffss(s1, s2)
  -| diffsc(s0, c0)
  -| diffsc(s0, c1)
  -| diffsc(s0, c2)
  -| diffsc(s0, c3)
  -| diffsc(s1, c0)
  -| diffsc(s1, c1)
  -| diffsc(s1, c2)
  -| diffsc(s1, c3)
  -| diffsc(s2, c0)
  -| diffsc(s2, c1)
  -| diffsc(s2, c2)
  -| diffsc(s2, c3)
} = {
  eqcomd(cfv(chash, co(c1, c4, c3)), cfv(chash, co(c1, c5, co(c3, caddc, nat2))), w3a(wcel(c0, cfrgr), wcel(c1, c2), wcel(c3, cn)))

  ovexd(c1, c5, co(c3, caddc, nat2), w3a(wcel(c0, cfrgr), wcel(c1, c2), wcel(c3, cn)))
  numclwlk2lem2f1o(s0, s1, s2, hs0, c0, c1, c2, c3, cmpt(hs0, co(c1, c5, co(c3, caddc, nat2)), co(cv(hs0), cpfx, co(c3, caddc, nat1))), c5, c4)
  eqid(cmpt(hs0, co(c1, c5, co(c3, caddc, nat2)), co(cv(hs0), cpfx, co(c3, caddc, nat1))))
  diffss.ex(s0, hs0)

blocks.name: numclwwlk2
blocks.content: Statement 10 in [Huneke] p. 2: "If n > 1, then the number of closed n-walks v(0) ... v(n-2) v(n-1) v(n) from v = v(0) = v(n) ... with v(n-2) =/= v is k^(n-2) - f(n-2)." According to ~ rusgrnumwlkg , we have k^(n-2) different walks of length (n-2): v(0) ... v(n-2). From this number, the number of closed walks of length (n-2), which is f(n-2) per definition, must be subtracted, because for these walks v(n-2) =/= v(0) = v would hold. Because of the friendship condition, there is exactly one vertex v(n-1) which is a neighbor of v(n-2) as well as of v(n)=v=v(0), because v(n-2) and v(n)=v are different, so the number of walks v(0) ... v(n-2) is identical with the number of walks v(0) ... v(n), that means each (not closed) walk v(0) ... v(n-2) can be extended by two edges to a closed walk v(0) ... v(n)=v=v(0) in exactly one way. (Contributed by Alexander van der Vekens, 6-Oct-2018.) (Revised by AV, 31-May-2021.) (Revised by AV, 1-May-2022.)

blocks.name: numclwwlk3
blocks.content: Statement 12 in [Huneke] p. 2: "Thus f(n) = (k - 1)f(n - 2) + k^(n-2)." - the number of the closed walks v(0) ... v(n-2) v(n-1) v(n) is the sum of the number of the closed walks v(0) ... v(n-2) v(n-1) v(n) with v(n-2) = v(n) (see ~ numclwwlk1 ) and with v(n-2) =/= v(n) (see ~ numclwwlk2 ): f(n) = kf(n-2) + k^(n-2) - f(n-2) = (k-1)f(n-2) + k^(n-2). (Contributed by Alexander van der Vekens, 26-Aug-2018.) (Revised by AV, 6-Mar-2022.)

blocks.name: numclwwlk4
blocks.content: The total number of closed walks in a finite simple graph is the sum of the numbers of closed walks starting at each of its vertices. (Contributed by Alexander van der Vekens, 7-Oct-2018.) (Revised by AV, 2-Jun-2021.) (Revised by AV, 7-Mar-2022.) (Proof shortened by AV, 28-Mar-2022.)
blocks.origin:
thm numclwwlk4(setvar s0, class c0, class c1, class c2) {
  |- wi(wa(wcel(c0, cfusgr), wcel(c1, cn)), wceq(cfv(chash, co(c1, cclwwlkn, c0)), csu(s0, c2, cfv(chash, co(cv(s0), cfv(cclwwlknon, c0), c1)))))
  -| wceq(c2, cfv(cvtx, c0))
  -| diffsc(s0, c0)
  -| diffsc(s0, c1)
  -| diffsc(s0, c2)
} = {
  eqtrd(cfv(chash, co(c1, cclwwlkn, c0)), csu(s0, c2, cfv(chash, co(cv(s0), cfv(cclwwlknon, c0), c1))), cfv(chash, ciun(s0, c2, co(cv(s0), cfv(cclwwlknon, c0), c1))), wa(wcel(c0, cfusgr), wcel(c1, cn)))

  syl(wa(wcel(c0, cfusgr), wcel(c1, cn)), wceq(co(c1, cclwwlkn, c0), ciun(s0, c2, co(cv(s0), cfv(cclwwlknon, c0), c1))), wcel(c0, cusgr))
  adantr(wcel(c0, cfusgr), wcel(c1, cn), wcel(c0, cusgr))
  fusgrusgr(c0)
  clwwlknun(s0, c0, c1, c2)
  hashiun(s0, c2, co(cv(s0), cfv(cclwwlknon, c0), c1), wa(wcel(c0, cfusgr), wcel(c1, cn)))
  adantr(wcel(c0, cfusgr), wcel(c1, cn), wcel(c2, cfn))
  adantr(wa(wcel(c0, cfusgr), wcel(c1, cn)), wcel(cv(s0), c2), wcel(co(cv(s0), cfv(cclwwlknon, c0), c1), cfn))

blocks.name: numclwwlk7lem
blocks.content: Lemma for ~ numclwwlk7 , ~ frgrreggt1 and ~ frgrreg : If a finite, nonempty friendship graph is ` K `-regular, the ` K ` is a nonnegative integer. (Contributed by AV, 3-Jun-2021.)

blocks.name: numclwwlk6
blocks.content: For a prime divisor ` P ` of ` K - 1 ` , the total number of closed walks of length ` P ` in a ` K `-regular friendship graph is equal modulo ` P ` to the number of vertices. (Contributed by Alexander van der Vekens, 7-Oct-2018.) (Revised by AV, 3-Jun-2021.) (Proof shortened by AV, 7-Mar-2022.)

blocks.name: numclwwlk7
blocks.content: Statement 14 in [Huneke] p. 2: "The total number of closed walks of length p [in a friendship graph] is (k(k-1)+1)f(p)=1 (mod p)", since the number of vertices in a friendship graph is (k(k-1)+1), see ~ frrusgrord0 or ~ frrusgrord , and p divides (k-1), i.e. (k-1) mod p = 0 => k(k-1) mod p = 0 => k(k-1)+1 mod p = 1. Since the null graph is a friendship graph, see ~ frgr0 , as well as k-regular (for any k), see ~ 0vtxrgr , but has no closed walk, see ~ 0clwlk0 , this theorem would be false for a null graph: ` ( ( # `` ( P ClWWalksN G ) ) mod P ) = 0 ` ` =/= 1 ` , so this case must be excluded (by assuming ` V =/= (/) ` ). (Contributed by Alexander van der Vekens, 1-Sep-2018.) (Revised by AV, 3-Jun-2021.)

blocks.name: numclwwlk8
blocks.content: The size of the set of closed walks of length ` P ` , ` P ` prime, is divisible by ` P ` . This corresponds to statement 9 in [Huneke] p. 2: "It follows that, if p is a prime number, then the number of closed walks of length p is divisible by p", see also ~ clwlksndivn . (Contributed by Alexander van der Vekens, 7-Oct-2018.) (Revised by AV, 3-Jun-2021.) (Proof shortened by AV, 2-Mar-2022.)

blocks.name: frgrreggt1
blocks.content: If a finite nonempty friendship graph is ` K `-regular with ` K > 1 ` , then ` K ` must be ` 2 ` . (Contributed by Alexander van der Vekens, 7-Oct-2018.) (Revised by AV, 3-Jun-2021.)

blocks.name: frgrreg
blocks.content: If a finite nonempty friendship graph is ` K `-regular, then ` K ` must be ` 2 ` (or ` 0 ` ). (Contributed by Alexander van der Vekens, 9-Oct-2018.) (Revised by AV, 3-Jun-2021.)

blocks.name: frgrregord013

blocks.name: frgrregord13
blocks.content: If a nonempty finite friendship graph is ` K `-regular, then it must have order 1 or 3. Special case of ~ frgrregord013 . (Contributed by Alexander van der Vekens, 9-Oct-2018.) (Revised by AV, 4-Jun-2021.)
blocks.origin:
thm frgrregord13(class c0, class c1, class c2) {
  |- wi(wa(w3a(wcel(c0, cfrgr), wcel(c1, cfn), wne(c1, emptycls)), wbr(c0, crusgr, c2)), wo(wceq(cfv(chash, c1), nat1), wceq(cfv(chash, c1), nat3)))
  -| wceq(c1, cfv(cvtx, c0))
} = {
  mpcom(wa(w3a(wcel(c0, cfrgr), wcel(c1, cfn), wne(c1, emptycls)), wbr(c0, crusgr, c2)), wo(wceq(cfv(chash, c1), nat1), wceq(cfv(chash, c1), nat3)), w3o(wceq(cfv(chash, c1), nat0), wceq(cfv(chash, c1), nat1), wceq(cfv(chash, c1), nat3)))
  syl3anc(wa(w3a(wcel(c0, cfrgr), wcel(c1, cfn), wne(c1, emptycls)), wbr(c0, crusgr, c2)), w3o(wceq(cfv(chash, c1), nat0), wceq(cfv(chash, c1), nat1), wceq(cfv(chash, c1), nat3)), wcel(c0, cfrgr), wcel(c1, cfn), wbr(c0, crusgr, c2))
  simpl1(wcel(c0, cfrgr), wcel(c1, cfn), wne(c1, emptycls), wbr(c0, crusgr, c2))
  simpl2(wcel(c0, cfrgr), wcel(c1, cfn), wne(c1, emptycls), wbr(c0, crusgr, c2))
  simpr(w3a(wcel(c0, cfrgr), wcel(c1, cfn), wne(c1, emptycls)), wbr(c0, crusgr, c2))
  frgrregord013(c0, c1, c2)
  3jaoi(wceq(cfv(chash, c1), nat0), wceq(cfv(chash, c1), nat1), wceq(cfv(chash, c1), nat3), wi(wa(w3a(wcel(c0, cfrgr), wcel(c1, cfn), wne(c1, emptycls)), wbr(c0, crusgr, c2)), wo(wceq(cfv(chash, c1), nat1), wceq(cfv(chash, c1), nat3))))
  com12(wceq(cfv(chash, c1), nat0), wa(w3a(wcel(c0, cfrgr), wcel(c1, cfn), wne(c1, emptycls)), wbr(c0, crusgr, c2)), wo(wceq(cfv(chash, c1), nat1), wceq(cfv(chash, c1), nat3)))

  3imp(wcel(c0, cfrgr), wcel(c1, cfn), wne(c1, emptycls), wi(wceq(cfv(chash, c1), nat0), wo(wceq(cfv(chash, c1), nat1), wceq(cfv(chash, c1), nat3))))
  a1i(wcel(c0, cfrgr), wi(wcel(c1, cfn), wi(wne(c1, emptycls), wi(wceq(cfv(chash, c1), nat0), wo(wceq(cfv(chash, c1), nat1), wceq(cfv(chash, c1), nat3))))))
  com23(wcel(c1, cfn), wne(c1, emptycls), wceq(cfv(chash, c1), nat0), wo(wceq(cfv(chash, c1), nat1), wceq(cfv(chash, c1), nat3)))

blocks.name: frgrogt3nreg
blocks.content: If a finite friendship graph has an order greater than 3, it cannot be ` k `-regular for any ` k ` . (Contributed by Alexander van der Vekens, 9-Oct-2018.) (Revised by AV, 4-Jun-2021.)

  -| wceq(c1, cfv(cvtx, c0))
  -| diffsc(s0, c0)
  -| diffsc(s0, c1)
} = {
  ralrimiva(s0, cn0, w3a(wcel(c0, cfrgr), wcel(c1, cfn), wbr(nat3, clt, cfv(chash, c1))), wn(wbr(c0, crusgr, cv(s0))))

  syl6an(wcel(cfv(chash, c1), cn0), wbr(nat3, clt, cfv(chash, c1)), wne(cfv(chash, c1), nat0), wcel(nat0, cr), wbr(nat0, clt, cfv(chash, c1)))

blocks.name: friendshipgt3
blocks.content: The friendship theorem for big graphs: In every finite friendship graph with order greater than 3 there is a vertex which is adjacent to all other vertices. (Contributed by Alexander van der Vekens, 9-Oct-2018.) (Revised by AV, 4-Jun-2021.)

blocks.name: friendship
blocks.content: The friendship theorem: In every finite (nonempty) friendship graph there is a vertex which is adjacent to all other vertices. This is Metamath 100 proof #83. (Contributed by Alexander van der Vekens, 9-Oct-2018.)
blocks.origin:
thm friendship(setvar s0, setvar s1, class c0, class c1) {
  |- wi(w3a(wcel(c0, cfrgr), wne(c1, emptycls), wcel(c1, cfn)), wrex(s0, c1, wral(s1, cdif(c1, csn(cv(s0))), wcel(cpr(cv(s0), cv(s1)), cfv(cedg, c0)))))
  -| wceq(c1, cfv(cvtx, c0))
  -| diffss(s0, s1)
  -| diffsc(s0, c0)
  -| diffsc(s0, c1)
  -| diffsc(s1, c0)
  -| diffsc(s1, c1)
} = {
  pm2.61i(wi(w3a(wcel(c0, cfrgr), wne(c1, emptycls), wcel(c1, cfn)), wrex(s0, c1, wral(s1, cdif(c1, csn(cv(s0))), wcel(cpr(cv(s0), cv(s1)), cfv(cedg, c0))))), wbr(nat3, clt, cfv(chash, c1)))
  ex(wbr(nat3, clt, cfv(chash, c1)), w3a(wcel(c0, cfrgr), wne(c1, emptycls), wcel(c1, cfn)), wrex(s0, c1, wral(s1, cdif(c1, csn(cv(s0))), wcel(cpr(cv(s0), cv(s1)), cfv(cedg, c0)))))
  syl3anc(wa(wbr(nat3, clt, cfv(chash, c1)), w3a(wcel(c0, cfrgr), wne(c1, emptycls), wcel(c1, cfn))), wrex(s0, c1, wral(s1, cdif(c1, csn(cv(s0))), wcel(cpr(cv(s0), cv(s1)), cfv(cedg, c0)))), wcel(c0, cfrgr), wcel(c1, cfn), wbr(nat3, clt, cfv(chash, c1)))
  simpr1(wbr(nat3, clt, cfv(chash, c1)), wcel(c0, cfrgr), wne(c1, emptycls), wcel(c1, cfn))
  simpr3(wbr(nat3, clt, cfv(chash, c1)), wcel(c0, cfrgr), wne(c1, emptycls), wcel(c1, cfn))

  friendshipgt3(s0, s1, c0, c1)
  com12(wn(wbr(nat3, clt, cfv(chash, c1))), w3a(wcel(c0, cfrgr), wne(c1, emptycls), wcel(c1, cfn)), wrex(s0, c1, wral(s1, cdif(c1, csn(cv(s0))), wcel(cpr(cv(s0), cv(s1)), cfv(cedg, c0)))))
  3imp(wcel(c0, cfrgr), wne(c1, emptycls), wcel(c1, cfn), wi(wn(wbr(nat3, clt, cfv(chash, c1))), wrex(s0, c1, wral(s1, cdif(c1, csn(cv(s0))), wcel(cpr(cv(s0), cv(s1)), cfv(cedg, c0))))))
  com14(wcel(c0, cfrgr), wne(c1, emptycls), wcel(c1, cfn), wn(wbr(nat3, clt, cfv(chash, c1))), wrex(s0, c1, wral(s1, cdif(c1, csn(cv(s0))), wcel(cpr(cv(s0), cv(s1)), cfv(cedg, c0)))))

  3syl(wa(wa(wn(wbr(nat3, clt, cfv(chash, c1))), wne(c1, emptycls)), wcel(c1, cfn)), wi(wcel(c0, cfrgr), wrex(s0, c1, wral(s1, cdif(c1, csn(cv(s0))), wcel(cpr(cv(s0), cv(s1)), cfv(cedg, c0))))), w3a(wcel(c1, cfn), wbr(nat1, cle, cfv(chash, c1)), wbr(cfv(chash, c1), cle, nat3)), wex(hs0, wex(hs1, wex(hs2, w3o(wceq(c1, csn(cv(hs0))), wceq(c1, cpr(cv(hs0), cv(hs1))), wceq(c1, ctp(cv(hs0), cv(hs1), cv(hs2))))))))
  impcom(wa(wn(wbr(nat3, clt, cfv(chash, c1))), wne(c1, emptycls)), wcel(c1, cfn), w3a(wcel(c1, cfn), wbr(nat1, cle, cfv(chash, c1)), wbr(cfv(chash, c1), cle, nat3)))
  mpcom(wcel(c1, cfn), wi(wa(wn(wbr(nat3, clt, cfv(chash, c1))), wne(c1, emptycls)), w3a(wcel(c1, cfn), wbr(nat1, cle, cfv(chash, c1)), wbr(cfv(chash, c1), cle, nat3))), wcel(cfv(chash, c1), cn0))
